Pre-Game Insights: In what very well may be a preview of the NBA Finals, the Celtics visit the Oklahoma City Thunder.
The Celtics opened the trip with wins over the Timberwolves and the Rockets.
This is the first of 2 games between these two teams this season.
The Celtics remain 2nd in the East, 4.5 games behind the first place Cleveland Cavaliers.
The Thunder are in first place in the West, 6.5 games ahead of 2nd place Memphis.
The Thunder currently have a 14 game win streak.
The Thunder made several key moves in the off season, including signing Isaiah Hartenstein and trading Josh Giddey for Alex Caruso.
Kristaps Porzingis returned to the starting lineup in the Celtics’ last game against the Rockets after missing 4 straight games with a sprained ankle.
Jalen Brown has missed the Celtics’ last two games with a shoulder strain and is questionable for this game.
Alex Caruso will miss his 7th game with a hip strain.
Chet Holmgren is out with a right iliac hip fracture.
Nikola Topic is out for the season with an ACL tear.
Others: The Celtics are 79-66 overall all time against the Thunder and they are 39-38 in games played on the road.
The Celtics are 12-3 on the road and they are 6-4 in their last 10 games.
The Thunder are 15-2 at home and they are 10-0 in their last 10 games.
The Thunder are 10-0 against Eastern Conference opponents.
Jrue Holiday vs Shai Gilgeous-Alexander is a key matchup, with Gilgeous-Alexander averaging 31.2 points per game.
Jayson Tatum vs Jalen Williams is another key matchup, with Williams averaging 20.9 points per game.
Kristaps Porzingis vs Isaiah Hartenstein is an honorable mention matchup, with Hartenstein averaging 12.2 points per game.
The Celtics need to focus on defense, rebounding, and taking care of the ball to win the game.
The Celtics are playing in their 3rd straight road game.
Joe Mazzulla led the Celtics to a championship in just his second season, while Thunder coach Mark Daigneault won the Coach of the Year honor last season.
Officiating is always an x-factor in the game.
